posts.post_content:
There're two big differences between this and Razor Boomerang, even in limited:  
  
1. Razor Boomerang only did 1 damage, but more importantly...  
2. Scars has infect.  
  
Pinging for 1 damage for 5 mana is almost certainly not worth it, especially as you can't apply abilities like deathtouch, lifelink and infect to the damage. However, 2 damage for 4 mana is very good, especially if you can do it in the form of poison counters or -1/-1 counters.  
  
The drawback isn't too bad at all. I won my prerelease with a GB infect deck, and this card certainly helped with a lot of them. With 2+ infecters on the board, I'd swap the arbalest between them and either give the opponent two poison counters without even attacking, or give a creature two -1/-1 counters (or more, depending on how feasible it was to block them and then ping them, or just ping them and let them through).  
  
This card is repeatable spot removal, colorless, and combos well with infect. There's every chance that it'll end up giving you c... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
There're two big differences between this and Razor Boomerang, even in limited:

1. Razor Boomerang only did 1 damage, but more importantly...
2. Scars has infect.

Pinging for 1 damage for 5 mana is almost certainly not worth it, especially as you can't apply abilities like deathtouch, lifelink and infect to the damage. However, 2 damage for 4 mana is very good, especially if you can do it in the form of poison counters or -1/-1 counters.

The drawback isn't too bad at all. I won my prerelease with a GB infect deck, and this card certainly helped with a lot of them. With 2+ infecters on the board, I'd swap the arbalest between them and either give the opponent two poison counters without even attacking, or give a creature two -1/-1 counters (or more, depending on how feasible it was to block them and then ping them, or just ping them and let them through).

This card is repeatable spot removal, colorless, and combos well with infect. There's every chance that it'll end up giving you c... (see all)

Posted By: kdraphael (3/11/2011 10:49:10 PM)

posts.post_content:
Remember that infinite mana combo in Myr decks?  
2 x [Myr Galvanizer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Myr Galvanizer)  
2 x Mana Myr ([Copper Myr](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Copper Myr), [Iron Myr](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Iron Myr), etc)  
  
Now slap this [Heavy Arbalest](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Heavy Arbalest) on one of those Mana Myr.  
  
- Tap Myr A w/ Heavy Arbalest for 2 damage at player.  
- Tap Myr B for 1 mana.  
- Pay 1 mana and tap Galvanizer A to untap Myr A and Myr B.  
- Rinse and repeat, alternating Galvanizers.  
Oh looky here, you just wiped out every single opponent in a multiplayer if I'm not mistaken.  
  
And hey, that [Platinum Emperion](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Platinum Emperion) getting you down?  
Slap that Arbalest on your [Plague Myr](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Plague Myr)/[Ichorclaw Myr](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ichorclaw Myr) instead!  
  
I can imagine it would be tricky to actually get this combo out on the battlefield, but I'm going to try it anyway with some blue control as a fun, casual deck.
posts.html:
Remember that infinite mana combo in Myr decks?
2 x Myr Galvanizer
2 x Mana Myr (Copper Myr, Iron Myr, etc)

Now slap this Heavy Arbalest on one of those Mana Myr.

- Tap Myr A w/ Heavy Arbalest for 2 damage at player.
- Tap Myr B for 1 mana.
- Pay 1 mana and tap Galvanizer A to untap Myr A and Myr B.
- Rinse and repeat, alternating Galvanizers.
Oh looky here, you just wiped out every single opponent in a multiplayer if I'm not mistaken.

And hey, that Platinum Emperion getting you down?
Slap that Arbalest on your Plague Myr/Ichorclaw Myr instead!

I can imagine it would be tricky to actually get this combo out on the battlefield, but I'm going to try it anyway with some blue control as a fun, casual deck.
Report Abuse

posts.post_content:
I agree this card is horrible unless you build your deck around it - whereupon it becomes epic. Late in the game you often have mana left over and creatures to spare, this card really comes alive then as well.  
  
I use it in a standard infinite combo deck - with [midnight guard](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=midnight guard) and three [fiend hunter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=fiend hunter)s It's preferable to Wolfhunter's quiver because before I get my combo it pings for twice the damage and I can usually get a creature into play every turn.
posts.html:
I agree this card is horrible unless you build your deck around it - whereupon it becomes epic. Late in the game you often have mana left over and creatures to spare, this card really comes alive then as well.

I use it in a standard infinite combo deck - with midnight guard and three fiend hunters It's preferable to Wolfhunter's quiver because before I get my combo it pings for twice the damage and I can usually get a creature into play every turn.

posts.post_content: I'm considering running this in my [Puresteel Paladin](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Puresteel Paladin)deck. Using the Paladin's free equip ability is what normally allows my [Mortarpod](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mortarpod) to finish my opponent by sacrificing each of my creatures to deal 1 damage. However, if I can get them to deal 3 damage by using the Arbalest, *then* sac to the [Mortarpod](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mortarpod), the game gets a lot quicker. Throw in some tokens from [Kemba, Kha Regent](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kemba, Kha Regent) or [Hero of Bladehold](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Hero of Bladehold), and you're really in business.
posts.html:
